definition: lit. to return to office after living as a hermit on Mount Dongshan (idiom); fig. to make a comeback
surname Dong
east/host (i.e. sitting on east side of guest)/landlord
surname Shan
mountain/hill/anything that resembles a mountain/CL:座[zuo4]/bundled straw in which silkworms spin cocoons/gable
again/once more/re-/second/another/then (after sth, and not until then)/no matter how ... (followed by an adjective or verb, and then (usually) 也[ye3] or 都[dou1] for emphasis)

to rise/to raise/to get up/to set out/to start/to appear/to launch/to initiate (action)/to draft/to establish/to get (from a depot or counter)/verb suffix, to start/starting from (a time, place, price etc)/classifier for occurrences or unpredictable events: case, instance/classifier for groups: batch, group

sentences.english: This is what got me fired and then hired.
sentences.chinese: 这就是为什么我被炒掉了能够又东山再起。

sentences.english: He that falls today maybe up tomorrow again.
sentences.chinese: 今日跌倒的他或许他日还能东山再起。

sentences.english: I don't believe that it will be possible to put young Cowperwood on his feet after this.
sentences.chinese: 我不相信这回能够使年轻的柯柏乌东山再起。

sentences.english: Al-Jadaa rebounded by selling her inventory and buying the equipment needed to start over.
sentences.chinese: 贾达通过变卖库存重新购买设备才得以东山再起。

sentences.english: After years of semi-retirement, the actressstaged a comeback.
sentences.chinese: 那位女明星在数年的半退休之后东山再起。

sentences.english: The boss lost all his money, but soon bobbed up again.
sentences.chinese: 这老板完全亏了本，但很快东山再起。

sentences.english: If escaping from death, need equestrian desert, in the future good stage a comeback.
sentences.chinese: 大难不死的话，就需要骑马逃跑，日后好东山再起。

sentences.english: It is difficult for Central and Southern Europe to resurge in the short term.
sentences.chinese: 中东欧经济短期内难以东山再起。

sentences.english: We suffered a terrible blow, but we are coming back.
sentences.chinese: 我们遭受了沉重一击，但是我们正在东山再起。

sentences.english: The boxer hopes to stage a come-back.
sentences.chinese: 这拳击家希望东山再起。

sentences.english: They didn't admit they were defeated; they began to recruit and attempted to stage a comeback.
sentences.chinese: 他们不承认失败，他们开始招兵妄图东山再起。

sentences.english: After a quietus of twenty years she returned.
Califano said Watergate would bring a Democratic revival.
sentences.chinese: 卡利法诺说，水门事件将帮助民主党人东山再起。

sentences.english: That fellow bobs up like a cork.
sentences.chinese: 那个人经过患难，东山再起。

sentences.english: Color PDP is just bob up like a cork, recurring in former days mien.
sentences.chinese: 彩色等离子体显示器正在东山再起，重显昔日风采。

definition: lit. to reorganize flags and drums (idiom); to regroup after a setback/to prepare for new initiatives/to attempt a comeback
to revitalize/to restore (prestige, prosperity etc)/revival/recovery
lit. the salted fish turns over (idiom)/fig. to experience a reversal of fortune
to overthrow/downfall/to fall from power/to go bankrupt
lit. to upend heaven and earth (idiom)/fig. to change the course of events/to turn things around
to fall from power/to collapse/demise
to win success and recognition (idiom)
to stand firmly/to gain a foothold/to establish oneself
one stumble, unable to rise (idiom); a setback leading to total collapse/ruined at a stroke/unable to recover after a minor hitch
lit. to return in a swirl of dust (idiom)/fig. to regroup and come back even stronger/to make a comeback
failed and wiped over the floor (idiom); to fail utterly/a crushing defeat/beaten and in a hopeless position
lit. the path exhausted, the end of the road (idiom); an impasse/in a plight with no way out/things have reached a dead end
to defeat/to strike down/to destroy
lit. to sleep on brushwood and taste gall (like King Gou Jian of Yue 勾踐|勾践[Gou1 Jian4]), in order to recall one's humiliations) (idiom)/fig. to maintain one's resolve for revenge
lit. to lie on firewood and taste gall (idiom); fig. suffering patiently, but firmly resolved on revenge
to go bankrupt/to become impoverished/bankruptcy
to work hard towards a turnaround/to fight to reverse sth
